user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DirOpen_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_DirOpen_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const char *local_path)
{
    DIR *                          dp = opendir(local_path);
    OS_impl_dir_internal_record_t *impl;

    if (dp == NULL)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    impl     = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_dir_table, *token);
    impl->dp = dp;

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_DirOpen_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_dir_internal_record_t OS_impl_dir_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_DIRS]
...
typedef struct
{
    DIR *dp;
} OS_impl_dir_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in the function are invariant. Specifically:
- The only conditional, if (dp == NULL), depends on dp which is assigned from opendir(local_path) and so is not a compile-time or runtime invariant.
- There are no loop constructs (for, while, do-while) whose controlling expressions could be invariant; the code contains no iteration statements to check against Rule 14.3.
- The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro expands to &tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))]; OS_ObjectIndexFromToken returns token->obj_idx, so the index is derived from the input token (not invariant). The macro invocation with *token resolves to &(*token) -> token, so it does not introduce an invariant controlling expression.
- Returning the macros OS_ERROR and OS_SUCCESS is not relevant to Rule 14.3 because they are used as return values, not as controlling expressions.
Given the absence of invariant controlling expressions and of any loops, there are no code fragments in this function that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
